title: Bump version.
body: Related #607

title: Migrate to Tokio 0.2
body:
Motivated to migrate RLS off Tokio 0.1 for IPC transport but since we're at it, it might make sense to migrate everything else in one fell swoop.

~This is a very early draft but opening it now to prevent duplicating work in case someone else starts working in it (or would like to help :grin:).~

Fixes #582
Fixes #485

title: [forwardport] Update `local` client to support middleware (Kudos Seun) (#589)
body:
* v15.0.1

* v15.0.1 => v15.1.0

* v15.0.1 => v15.1.0

* cargo fmt

* fix tests

* adds *_with_middleware methods

* remove Unpin bound, add documentation, cargo fmt

* 15.0.1

* bump to 15.1.0

Co-authored-by: Seun Lanlege <seunlanlege@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Niklas <niklasadolfsson1@gmail.com>

title: Expose direct configuration of max in and out buffer capacity
body:
Closes #590, see issue for feature description.

If not set, `max_in_buffer_capacity` and `max_out_buffer_capacity` explicitly defaults to 10,485,760, which is the same as [`parity-ws` `Settings::default`](https://github.com/paritytech/ws-rs/blob/be4d47575bae55c60d9f51b47480d355492a94fc/src/lib.rs#L254).

title: Fix publishing script.
body: We kept retrying `cargo publish` even on success, so the only way to go to the next crate was to actually have it failed and then `s` to skip re-trying.

title: update parking_lot to v0.11
body: Signed-off-by: koushiro <koushiro.cqx@gmail.com>

title: Update `local` client to support middleware (Kudos Seun)
body:
Previously the `jsonrpc_core_client::transports::local::connect` consumed a `Deref<Target=MetaIoHandler<TMetadata, NoopMiddleware>>`,

This PR corrects that behaviour allowing the local transport support other `Middleware` implementations

title: Update examples in top-level readme.
body: Closes #586

title: Use patched ws-rs
body: Revert to `ws-rs` once https://github.com/housleyjk/ws-rs/pull/328 is merged and published.

title: Use patched ws-rs
body: Revert to `ws-rs` once https://github.com/housleyjk/ws-rs/pull/328 is merged and published.

title: Resolve possible trait import conflict.
body: Since we do two glob imports, if there is `Future` trait imported (from `futures03`) in the upper scope the client generation breaks.

title: Remove failure dependency.
body: Resolves #578

title: Add missing user specified trait bounds in [rpc] macro
body: Fix #567

title: Migrate core to futures=0.3
body:
This is the first step towards #485 (also see #422). The PR rewrites `jsonrpc-core` & `jsonrpc-derive` & `jsonrpc-core-client` (but not transports) to be compatible with `futures=0.3`.

`jsonrpc-derive` is limited to return either `Result<_>` or `BoxFuture<Result<_>>` (see `WrapFuture` trait), supporting custom future types would require a bit more work. Actually it would be best to check out if we can integrate it with `async_trait`, so that the implementations can simply define `async` functions.

The transports (servers) currently run the futures in `compat` mode, they should be updated as well.

title: CI: some optimizations; new image
body:
- Linux CI image was changed to the new one with the latest `nightly` Rust, it's being tested against Substrate tests every night.
- `CARGO_TARGET_DIR` caching is enabled for linux builds
- some other optimizations

title: Bump `derive` version to v14.2.1
body: It'd be nice to have a release with #558 included. I missed it earlier, so it didn't make it into 14.2.

title: Bump quote crate version
body:
There was an issue with quote v1.0.2 which is why
we were pinned to v1.0.1. This issue has been fixed
so we don't need to be pinned anymore.

title: Allow skipping and retrying publishing.
body:
Towards idempotency :dancing_men: 

I think the next reasonable change would be to check version before publish and if it matches, skip by default, but propose to re-publish (maybe not even needed)?
But I had enough bash programming for today :)

The `set -x/+x` has been sprinkled to clean up the output a bit - I still like to see the commands that are actually made, but the looping/conditionals where causing havoc in the logs.

title: Place NumericIdProvider's Id behind an Arc
body:
Allows the Id to be moved safely between threads. Also
has the advantage of allowing NumericIdProvider to derive
`Clone`.

title: Use matches! macro
body:
Apparently our Windows runner has been updated, so this
should work now.

title: hosts: when binding to unspecified address allow requests from localhost
body:
Setting address to unspecified usually means that we're interested to listen on all interfaces so IMO it makes sense that we won't be filtering requests from localhost.

Found this while debugging substrate since when running with `--unsafe-rpc-external` we will bind to `0.0.0.0` (which is opaque to the user) and will enable host filtering. It was surprising to me that requests to localhost or `127.0.0.1` wouldn't work. If you prefer I can instead make sure that substrate always add `localhost` and `127.0.0.1` as allowed hosts but imo this is a nice default to have here.

title: Add a subscription manager
body:
I was implementing some pubsub APIs in Substrate, outside of `sc-rpc`, and got to a point where I needed something to execute the subscription Futures. There's nothing provided out of the box for doing that, so after talking with @tomusdrw we figured that it might be useful to have the [Substrate subscription manager](https://github.com/paritytech/substrate/blob/master/client/rpc-api/src/subscriptions.rs) be a part of the `pubsub` crate.

What I've done is I've stolen that code and changed it to try and be a little less opinionated. One concern I have though is that I've changed `SubscriptionId` to now take a generic parameter, `N`, to avoid only working with `u64` ids, and I think this will break people's code.

I'm looking for feedback on whether the general approach is alright, and if the change to `SubscriptionId` is acceptable.

title: Wait for published version to be available
body:
When I was publishing `14.1.0` the publish script repeatedly failed where a dependency on a previously published crate was not yet available.

This PR waits for the published version to be available after publishing each package before moving on to the next one.

Note that I have only tested this with the `cargo publish` commented out, not with an actual release.

title: 14.1.0 bump
body:
## Release notes

- Wait for http server to close on Drop. (#543)
- Add "Accept:application/json" header for all requests. (#544) 
- Client call with named params (#541)

title: Add "Accept:application/json" header for all requests.
body:
As discussed in #542 .
Add accept header for client http requests so that it can work with some other libs/existing servers that require this field.

title: Wait for http server to close on Drop.
body: To be honest I'm not 100% sure that this is the right thing to do. Blocking on `drop` does not sound like a good idea to me, but we do that already for WS server (and it seems desired for instance in `substrate`), hence opted to implement for HTTP as well.

title: Client call with named params
body:
# Add named_params option to RPC derive macro

Closes #540 

While the server generated by the derive macro doesn't support calling functions with named params some other systems do (some exclusively). It would still be nice to use the clean derive macro syntax to generate a client in this case.

This PR adds a flag `named_params` to the rpc method attribute. Example:
```rust
#[rpc(name = "add", named_params)]
fn add(&self, a: u32, b: u32) -> Result<String>;
```
In this case the json-rpc call object produced by calling the generated method on a client will have a params object that takes the key names from the function parameter names.
```json
{
   "jsonrpc": "2.0",
   "params": {"a": 4, "b": 2},
   ...
}
```

As the server doesn't support this it is important that this cannot be used when deriving server RPC methods. The rpc derive macro will throw a compile time error if the `named_params` switch is used in any case other than `#[rpc(client)]`. See (derive/tests/ui/attr-named-params-on-server.rs)

title: bump parking_lot and patch versions
body: similar to https://github.com/paritytech/parity-common/pull/332 (but here `parking_lot` is not exposed in the public API, right?)

title: Fix a broken import in stdio example
body: This is a minor fix which allows the example code in `stdio/README.md` to compile.

title: Fix ServerBuilder::cors_max_age doc comment time unit
body:
#### Problem
The `cors_max_age` doc comment states that the age is specified in millis. But according to the [MDN Docs](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Access-Control-Max-Age), the header is specified in seconds.

#### Fix
Update doc comment to say "seconds"

title: [client] notify subscriber if subscription was rejected
body:
Closes #508 

- [x] test it works

title: New publish script.
body:
Tag in one go, instead of crate-by-crate.
Don't fail in case tagging fails.

title: Bump parity-tokio-ipc
body: The new version compiles on android 😅

title: 14.0.5 bump
body:
Release notes:
1. Regular updates (env_logger 0.6->0.7, websocket 0.23->0.24)
2. IPC socket permissioning (https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpc/pull/519)
3. Support `serde_json` with `arbitrary_precision` feature.
4. Modify the HTTP server requests handling (avoid `buffer_unordered` with aribtrary limit in favour of spawning tasks on the runtime).

title: Fix basic example from on the readme file
body:
- Adding right modules to run the example
- Removing call to unwrap on server wait.

title: workaround serde deserializing incorrectly when arbitrary_precision enabled
body:
serde deserializes incorrectly when arbitrary precision is enabled.

fixes #520 

The workaround is to deserialize into `Value` before `ClientResponse`. This is gated under the feature `arbitrary_precision` in core-client and `transports`.

title: Upgrade parity-tokio-ipc
body: The newest version of the library supports using `SecurityAttributes` for setting socket permissions on *nix.

title: Avoid using buffer_unordered
body:
...and rather spawn tasks directly on the executor.

This should fix issues with unresponsive server, while still not breaking the previous fix causing the server to not be closed properly when there were pending requests. Now we use `Weak` references and only try to upgrade them when we handle the request.

title: Avoid closing HTTP server on connection error
body: Fixes: #514

title: Multiple methods to initiate same subscriptions
body: @tomusdrw probably some integration test missing for this, but can't find where to place it

title: Bump version.
body: CC @niklasad1

title: Update syn & co
body: Closes #505

title: Fix race condition on `wait()`
body:
Manually dropping the future passed from `Future::select` before sending
`done_tx` prevents the race condition.

`Future::select` pass the unresolved future, which is a `Server` holding
`rpc_handler`, to the following callback. Therefore, it is dropped after
the `done_tx.send(())` after the callback exits.
It is possible that the thread that has executed `wait()`, which is
usually the main thread, terminates before the thread sending `done_tx`
drops `rpc_handler`.
Static variables are destructed at the end of termination of the main
thread, and then a segfault occurs when the thread dropping the
rpc_handler accesses the variables.

I closed the previous PR (https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpc/pull/501).
Sorry for the confusion.

title: ignore dropped connections
body:
Previously If there's no `peer_addr` on the socket, this causes the tcp-server to panic. 

https://github.com/paritytech/jsonrpc/blob/44184766aeb59a95b4d6f4c7eaff0c9e1ef278eb/tcp/src/server.rs#L87-L93

Instead of panicking this PR instead ignores the connection as it has most likely been dropped by the client.

closes #500

title: Solve compiler error when serde is not a dependency of user project (#481)
body:
Use `serde` directly instead of ask for user of the library to add it as a
dependency.

Tests are modified since this is a ui change.

The doc comment gives an example using `#[rpc(server)]` instead of original
`#[rpc]`, telling users that this attribute has an option to be used to
configure it.

title: Bump to 14.0
body:
I believe that #495 was quite a significant change and it deserves a major version bump.

Even though technically the threading behaviour was buggy, updating to post #495 will cause a huge change in perceived performance (as by default it would run less threads).

title: Fix threading and closing of servers
body:
This PRs attempts to clean up the spawned threads (Closes #425).
Currently every `RpcEventLoop` spawns a bunch of threads that depend on the number of cores (tokio runtime) + one thread that waits for the runtime to complete. Instead we just spawn `tokio::runtime` with one thread and a right name.

Also we avoid calling `tokio::spawn` when handling incoming connections in various server implementations to ensure that when the server is closed all connections are dropped as well (currently, they are still being polled by the runtime so you have to wait for them to close or timeout).

title: Run format only on stable @ linux.

title: Add `iter` and `IntoIterator` to `IoHandler`
body: Context: To be able to get all methods current in `IoHandler` and add a "meta" call that returns all available methods.
